bibl.title: Letter fragment from Samuel Taylor Darling, [19--]

div1.p: Darling writes that he has not found abnormalities in blood of yellow fever cases. He had hoped to join the yellow fever work, but has been advised to stay with Department of Hygiene, in Sao Paulo, Brazil.

div1.head: Letter fragment from Samuel Taylor Darling, [19--]
div1.p:
Kendall thought that the eosinophiles exploded and were found in a broken, spread out
condition on the slide in cases of yellow fever, but this I have very commonly observed
in many films in other conditions. I made no observations on what is known as the
Arneth count. You will find this has been gone into by BranelBreinl and a man with an Irish
name, who did some work in Guayaquil. I think it has all been published in the Annals
of Tropical Medicine and Parasitology, of Liverpool. I am sorry I can not give you
the exact reference.

I had hoped to be associated with you and General Gorgas in the Yellow Fever
work which you are now undertaking, but Dr. Rose seems to feel that I had better stay
here and look after the Department of Hygiene in São Paulo. If you get down as far
as Rio, you must let me know, for Mrs. Darling and Virginia as well as myself will be
delighted to see you.

With the best wishes to you and your family and with the very kindest
regards I am
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Samuel T. Darling I had dengue in Malacca two years ago
and understood how you must have felt when
you had it in Cuba
STD.AM
